article.title: Geometric Optimal Control and Applications to Aerospace

multiple_choice_question.text: What aspect of an ascent trajectory does Figure 1 primarily illustrate?
choices: The sequence of events and safety constraints involved.
The specific aerodynamic forces acting on the vehicle.
The precise calculation of propellant mass needed.
The variations in Earth\'s gravitational field during ascent.

multiple_choice_question.text: What key difference between ascent/reentry missions and orbital missions is highlighted in Figure 2?
choices: The significantly longer duration of orbital missions.
The reliance on impulsive velocity changes in orbital maneuvers.
The crucial role of ground tracking stations in orbital missions.
The dominant influence of atmospheric drag in orbital missions.

multiple_choice_question.text: What challenge specific to low thrust orbit raising does Figure 3 depict?
choices: Accounting for the Earth\'s shadow, which necessitates engine cut-offs.
Compensating for the significant aerodynamic drag at high altitudes.
Maneuvering within the gravitational influence of multiple celestial bodies.
Precisely targeting the Lagrange points for fuel-efficient transfers.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Formula (1) represent in the context of optimal control problems?
choices: The cost function to be minimized.
The constraints on the control input.
The differential equations governing the system\'s evolution.
The terminal conditions for the trajectory.
